content:
The Act is titled the "National Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2007" and includes definitions. The "National Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2007" defines key terms related to infrastructure, including acquisition, commission, construction, and infrastructure itself. The "National Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2007" defines infrastructure as nonmilitary structures, facilities, equipment, and nonstructural elements, including surface transportation facilities like roads, bridges, highways, and rail. The Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users (Public Law 109-59; 119 Stat. 1471) covers various types of infrastructure including mass transit facilities, airports, water supply systems, wastewater treatment systems, stormwater treatment systems, waterways, levees, and flood damage reduction facilities. Nonstructural elements include features that preserve natural processes, landforms, vegetated buffers, wetlands, and techniques that slow, filter, and store stormwater runoff. It also includes designs that percolate, filter, store, evaporate, and detain water close to its source, as well as features that minimize impervious surfaces to slow runoff and allow precipitation to percolate. Maintenance refers to regularly scheduled activities like routine repairs to ensure infrastructure operates efficiently. Rehabilitation involves actions to extend the useful life or improve existing infrastructure, such as correcting deficiencies, modernizing equipment, and removing deteriorated or obsolete infrastructure. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. The National Commission on the Infrastructure of the United States is established to ensure that the country's infrastructure meets current and future demand, facilitates economic growth, ensures public safety, and is developed sustainably. The Commission will consist of 8 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, and majority leader of the Senate. The National Commission on the Infrastructure of the United States will consist of 8 members appointed by various leaders in Congress. Each member must have experience in relevant fields and represent different geographical regions. Members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment and serve for the Commission's duration. The National Commission on the Infrastructure of the United States will have 8 members appointed for life, with vacancies filled within 30 days. The Commission must hold an initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings will be called by the Chairperson or majority request. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making. The Commission must select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. SEC. 4. DUTIES. The Commission is required to complete a study by February 15, 2009, on the state of the infrastructure of the United States, including its capacity for economic development and competitiveness, as well as the age and condition of public infrastructure. The curr_chunk discusses the methods and trends in financing infrastructure construction, maintenance, and rehabilitation. It also highlights investment requirements to maintain and improve infrastructure. The curr_chunk discusses the projected amount of need expenditures will meet in the future, investment requirements, trends in infrastructure procurement methods, construction methods, materials, and the impact of local development patterns. The curr_chunk focuses on the impact of local development patterns on demand for Federal funding of infrastructure, deferred maintenance, and collateral impact of deteriorated infrastructure. Recommendations include developing a Federal infrastructure plan detailing national priorities, infrastructure improvements, and criteria for inventorying existing and needed infrastructure improvements. The Commission is tasked with assessing infrastructure improvements, developing uniform criteria for inventories, and maintaining accessible data. They are also required to propose guidelines for reporting construction, acquisition, and maintenance data by Federal agencies. The Commission must submit a detailed statement of findings, conclusions, and recommendations to Congress by February 15, 2010. The Commission will propose administrative actions for various time periods as deemed appropriate. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, as outlined in Section 5, has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, accept gifts, and enter into contracts to carry out its duties under this Act. The Commission, under the guidance of the Commission, conducts the study required under section 4(a). The Commission may use the United States mails in the same manner and under the same conditions as other agencies of the Federal Government. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Commission members serve without pay but receive a per diem allowance for travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the majority of the Commission members. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. The maximum pay for employees (excluding the executive director) is capped at the rate for Executive Level IV. Additionally, federal government employees can be detailed to work for the Commission. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The Secretary of the Army can provide necessary support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 7. REPORTS. The Commission must submit an interim report within 1 year of its initial meeting, detailing progress, meetings, and hearings to the President and specific Congressional committees. Upon termination, a final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation must be submitted to the President. The Commission must submit a final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation to the President and specific Congressional committees. The report must be made available to the public electronically in a user-friendly format. SEC. 8. FUNDING.

For fiscal years 2008 through 2010, the Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency shall transfer a total of $1,250,000 to the Commission for carrying out this Act. Additionally, the Secretary of the Army shall transfer $250,000 from the General Expenses account of the Corps of Engineers for the same purpose.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will terminate on September 30, 2010.
